case_vignette: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of right foot pain for 3 months. She has a burning sensation in the plantar area between the third and fourth metatarsals that radiates to the third and fourth digits. She had a right distal radius fracture that was treated with a splint and physical therapy three months ago. She is an account executive and wears high heels to work every day. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right lower extremity shows intact skin. The posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses are palpable. When pressure is applied to the sole of the foot between the metatarsal heads the patient feels pain and there is an audible click. Tapping on the affected area causes pain that shoots into the third and fourth digits.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having pain in my right foot for 3 months, and it feels like a burning sensation on the bottom side that shoots into my middle toes.
Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications?
No, I don't have any other medical conditions or take any medications.
Do you have a family history of diabetes or any other nerve-related conditions?
I don't know of any family history of diabetes or nerve-related conditions.
Are you male or female and how old are you?
I am a 45-year-old woman.
Have you noticed any changes in the color of the skin on your foot or any numbness in your toes?
No, the skin on my foot looks normal, and I haven't felt any numbness in my toes.
**Final Diagnosis:** Morton's neuroma
